title: Sesame Street reveals newest Muppet lives in care because her mum is battling addiction
text:

Sesame Street has introduced a new Muppet that lives in foster care because her mum is battling an opioid addiction.

The character, named Karli, has been created to teach children that grown-up problems aren't their fault.

She joined the show back in April as someone living in care and now has been given a full story line about why she was moved to a new home.

A touching clip from the show features Karli and Elmo talking to a young girl called Salia Woodbury, whose parents are in recovery in real life.

Karli tells her: "My mum was having a hard time with addiction and it felt like I was the only on going through it.

(Image: SESAME STREET)

(Image: SESAME STREET)

"But now I've met so many other kids like us."

"I’m so glad we’re friends, Salia," she says at the end of the clip.

"Me too Karli," Salia says.

"Can I have a hug?" Karli says and they embrace.

(Image: SESAME STREET)

In another clip, Elmo's dad tells him: "Karli's mummy has a disease called addiction, addiction makes people feel like they need a grown-up drink called alcohol or another kind of drug to feel OK.

"That can make a person act strange in ways they can't control ."

Sesame Workshop, the non-profit organization behind Sesame Street, said the character shares the "words children need to hear most: You are not alone. You will be taken care of.

(Image: SESAME STREET)

"Addiction is a sickness and, as with any sickness, people need help to get better. And most importantly: It’s not your fault."

Salia's parents Sam and Jaana Woodbury, from Orange County, California, said they welcome the awareness the show has brought to the issue.

Janna, who has been in recovery for about eight years, told the site: "When I was going through addiction, I felt extremely alone and isolated. I didn't have any connection to the outside world.

"I think it's amazing that Sesame Street is using their platform to share resources to help other women and fathers."
